Description: Cube-shaped canopic chest, made of wood covered by a thin layer of plaster and painted yellow. One line of hieroglyphic inscription written across each side, with added vertical lines near the corners. All the hieroglyphs are painted blue-green. The texts invoke various deities on behalf of the deceased, including the four sons of Horus, Neith, Osiris, Isis and Nephthys. The owner of the chest was called Mesehti.With the box are some planks from the lid, in two groups, one consisting of two boards and the other of five.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Bibliographic references: Zitman 2010 / The necropolis of Assiut: a case study of local Egyptian funerary culture from the Old Kingdom to the end of the Middle Kingdom (I, 330; II, 234)
Ryan 1988 / The Archaeological Excavations of David George Hogarth at Asyut, Egypt 1906/7 (25)
Associated names: Named in inscription: Sons of Horus
